It can be sung as a solo, a duet or in a group with or without musical accompaniment. ## History Bongai reached its peak of fame in the 1950s where it was considered a must in any ceremony held especially wedding ceremonies in Negeri Sembilan. It is also performed for specific purposes, especially as entertainment during the evenings, after work. Bongai simply refers to the ceremony of reciting a poem through song, it is sometimes accompanied by instrumentation. It was historically performed at night. ## Instruments The musical instruments used in Bongai include: [violin](/wiki/Violin), [rebana](/wiki/Rebana), [gong](/wiki/Gong), [gendang](/wiki/Gendang), [salung](/wiki/Saluang) and tumbuk kalang. Besides these basic instruments, other instruments such as [caklempong](/wiki/Talempong), bangsi, [accordion](/wiki/Accordion) and others can also be used. Example of songs sung as part of Bongai include: - "Anak Bocek" - "Budu Landai" - "Cantik Manis" - "Donak Donai" - "Kapeh" - Music portal - Malaysia portal - [Gamelan](/wiki/Gamelan) - [Kulintangan](/wiki/Kulintang)
